message.content:
cs.CL, cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.IR, cs.NE. 

This paper is about developing an abstractive summarization system that does not rely on paired articles and summaries, which is a common problem in natural language processing (NLP) and information retrieval (IR). Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.CL (Computation and Language), which deals with NLP and related tasks such as summarization, machine translation, and text generation. 

The paper also uses unsupervised and synthetic data to train the system, which suggests a focus on machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI), hence cs.AI is another likely sub-category. 

Furthermore, the paper involves selecting salient sentences and paraphrasing them, which are tasks related to text mining and information extraction, thus cs.IR (Information Retrieval) is also a possible sub-category. 

The paper also mentions achieving promising results on a benchmark, which implies a focus on evaluation and performance metrics, hence cs.LG (Machine Learning) is another possible sub-category. 

Finally, the paper uses a sentence extractor and abstractor, which are tasks related to natural language generation and generation models, suggesting cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing) as a possible sub-category.
